title: Investigative task - keyboard and data entry speed

content.description: Researchers are studying two different designs of computer keyboards, J and K, to investigate the effectiveness of the design on the speed of data entry. The researchers believe there is a tendency for people entering data with keyboard J to have faster entry times compared with people entering data with keyboard K. Using the same set of data for entry, the researchers randomly assigned <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to keyboard J and <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>6</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> people to keyboard K and recorded the number of seconds each person took to enter the data. The following dotplots show the observed entry times for the two keyboards.
content.question: (a) Explain why it is not appropriate to conduct a two-sample <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>-test for the difference in population means.

frqParts.text: (a) Explain why it is not appropriate to conduct a two-sample <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>-test for the difference in population means.
(b) Based on the dotplots, explain why it might be more appropriate to compare population medians instead of population means.

One test used to compare population medians is the Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test. Under the assumption that the shape and variability of the distributions are the same, the test uses the rankings of the combined observed values. To conduct the test, the entry times for keyboards J and K are combined into one group and then ranked from <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="n sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , the total number of observed values in the combined group. The observed entry times, in seconds, for both keyboard types are shown in the following table.

Observed Entry Times

J

K

 <math alttext="305" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>305</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) Consider the observed entry times for keyboards J and K.

(i) Complete the following table to assign ranks to the observed entry times for keyboards J and K combined.

Rank

(ii) Use the completed table in (i) to calculate the sum of the ranks assigned to each keyboard.

Sum of ranks for J <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>S</mi> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi>J</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C72@</annotation> </semantics> </math>:

Sum of ranks for K <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>S</mi> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi>K</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C73@</annotation> </semantics> </math>:

The hypotheses for the Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test are as follows.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>H</mi> <mi>O</mi> </msub> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3985@</annotation> </semantics> </math>: The median of the distribution of entry times for all users of keyboard J and the median of the distribution of entry times for all users of keyboard K are the same.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>H</mi> <mi>a</mi> </msub> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3997@</annotation> </semantics> </math>: The median of the distribution of entry times for all users of keyboard J is less than the median of the distribution of entry times for all users of keyboard K.

The test static <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mi>W</mi> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHXgaruavP1wzZbItLDhis9wBH5garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYxf9irVeeu0dXdI8qqqj=hEeeu0xXdbba9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXdbPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaiaaciWacmaadaGabiaaeaGaauaaaOqaaiaadEfaaaa@3894@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for the test is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>W</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>S</mi> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi>J</mi> </msub> <mo>−</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>J</mi> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>J</mi> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4654@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>J</mi> </msub> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@39C6@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is the number of observations for keyboard J.

(d) Use the formula to calculate the test statistic <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mi>W</mi> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHXgaruavP1wzZbItLDhis9wBH5garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYxf9irVeeu0dXdI8qqqj=hEeeu0xXdbba9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXdbPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaiaaciWacmaadaGabiaaeaGaauaaaOqaaiaadEfaaaa@3894@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for the keyboard data.

There are <math alttext="462" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>462</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> possible assignments of <math alttext="11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ranks to <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Js and <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Ks. If the null hypothesis is true, the <math alttext="462" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>462</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assignments are equally likely. The following graph shows the sampling distribution of all possible values of <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resulting from the <math alttext="462" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>462</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assignments.

(e) The least possible value of <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sampling distribution is <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Find the value of <math alttext="S R sub J" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="W equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(ii) Assign <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ranks to keyboard J and <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ranks to keyboard K so that <math alttext="W equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show your assignments by completing the following table.

Rank
 <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Keyboard

(f) Use the test statistic from part (d) and the graph of the sampling distribution to decide whether there is convincing statistical evidence, at the level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, that the median of the distribution for all users of keyboard J is less than the median of the distribution for all users of keyboard K. Support your answer.

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Describe data presented numerically or graphically.
